The hon. member from the New Democratic Party says bring in the bill. He would have generic copies of textbooks. That is an interesting policy. Maybe the NDP would like to propose that we should have a debate on that.
The reality is that in all modem societies we recognize something called intellectual property. If you create the product of your mind, just as the product of your hands is yours, it is immoral for governments to come along and say that the product of your mind belongs to the common good because what that does is it turns off minds.
In terms of the pharmaceutical industry what we had prior to Bill C-22 was the situation where it simply did not make sense to do research in Canada because you spent $150 million to $200 million to develop a new drug. You spend that money, you create a new drug. If it has any market at all, it is because it helps people with their illnesses. And then you say: "But you, the creator, do not have the exclusive right to enjoy the fruits of invention; somebody else will enjoy them".
Then what happens is that there is not much research in Canada. Indeed, prior to 1987 pharmaceutical companies operating in Canada spent about 6 per cent of their total sales on research versus a world average of 10, 11 or 12 per cent, in that order. We had about half the research.
Where is it? Tell us where.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
The hon. member from Kingston should listen rather than heckle from his seat.
What has happened now is that the pharmaceutical industry said to us in 1987 that if we passed Bill C-22 it would raise the level of R and D in Canada to international levels by 1996, 10 per cent by 1996. Well, what happened in 1991? It was 9.7 per cent. This year it has already exceeded what had been committed to by 1996. Why? Because once you provide some protection for the fruits of research you get research. Lo and behold, Canadian universities and medical establishments, Canadian laboratories have shown that they are very good. We
November 17, 1992

have some excellent people. Given the opportunity to pursue research and the opportunity to enjoy the fruits of that research, Canadians have responded.
The November 10 issue of The Globe and Mail on the report on health and pharmaceuticals says: "Robust industry defies sick economy". There are several pages about how robust the pharmaceutical industry is in Canada as a result of Bill C-22. What do we have? We have investments in research and development near international levels finally. We have a robust industry employing people and growing.
I will never forget the young man who stopped me on a street in Montreal and said: "Thank you, Mr. Andre. I have been working in California since graduating with my Ph.D. in biochemistry. As a result of Bill C-221 have been able to come back to Canada and work in my home country doing research and development". The member from the New Democratic Party over there chuckles about this. He thinks it is pretty funny that we provide an environment for Canadian scientists to work in Canada.
What was said about Bill C-22? Let me read you some quotes on Bill C-22, one by the now NDP leader, but not then: "Estimates suggest that it will double or even triple the cost of prescription drugs in the country". What happened? They actually went down in real terms. I think it was the member for Essex-Windsor: "The bill will bring Canada dramatically higher drug prices and very little research". Wrong on both counts. More research, lower prices. What did the then leader of the Liberal Party say? "Consumers could wind up paying billions more under C-22." Wrong, dead wrong.
Where are the facts on this? Who says so?

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will conclude by reading a quote from an article in The Ottawa Citizen of October 6 because I think it explains why we are doing it: "Canada risks becoming a mere bystander in the global race for new drugs and treatments unless the government passes its controversial drug patent law, a group of researchers warned Monday. The real losers are going to be Canadians in need of innovative medical treatment, said Dr. Howard Dickson, chairman of the Coalition for Biomedical and Health Research and associate dean of research at Dalhousie University's faculty of medicine". It goes on to say: "The coalition is urging the passage of C-91".
The reality is that the scientists of this country want us to pass this bill because it is right. Those who understand what research and intellectual property is about want us to pass it because it is right. Those who look fairly at the success of Bill C-22 recognize that this is a move in the right direction that will produce more research, better drugs for Canadians, more jobs for Canadians, and in fact is the kind of legislation that any intelligent government would pass.
That is why I am pleased to support it, Mr. Speaker.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to speak on Bill C-91. I want to address three issues: compulsory licensing, research and development in jobs and the cost of pharmaceutical drugs. First of all, I want to assure my hon. colleagues that I have in fact looked at the research and I am going to try to make a case which I think is fair.
We have to understand that compulsory licensing was brought in because the prices of pharmaceuticals in Canada were really much higher than in most countries of the world. Because it was difficult to try to make these medications available to our population, there was a different way to do it. In fact it was the right hon. member for Vancouver-Quadra who amended the Patent Act so that holders of drug patents no longer had a monopoly on the production and the bill established, as I was indicating, a system of compulsory licensing whereby generic drug companies could produce a patent drug

Government Orders
by receiving the compulsory licence and paying the licence holder a royalty fee.
That was a step forward because this practice increased competition in the industry and lowered the aggregate price of drugs sold in Canada. It also had the effect of helping keep medicare and health costs stable. That has been demonstrated in a number of studies.
I want to point out a couple of studies that have dealt with that. For example, the report of the inquiry into the pharmaceutical industry, the Eastman report, stated that by 1983 the multinationals had lost only 3.1 per cent of the Canadian market to generic competition and the profit levels of the multinational companies in Canada were higher than in most well developed countries of the world.
It goes to show that in spite of these changes, that permitted keeping the cost down and therefore gave more access to Canadians generally and it did not have a large a large debilitating effect on the patent drug industry.
At the same time, the system of compulsory licensing brought the price of drugs in Canada under control. Here is where Eastman reports again. The system of compulsory licensing in Canada saved Canadian consumers $211 million.
It has also created a generic drug industry that employs over 2,500 people and does business in excess of $400 million. That is in comparison to multinationals which employ about 17,000 people and have a business of $4 billion, which is significantly larger.
I think most people would agree that in 1984 Canada was well served by a policy of compulsory licensing and medical drug patents. Why is it that the government decided to offer more protection? Why did it offer a monopoly if you wish to the multinationals? Why, when it was working perfectly well?
Since the passage of that infamous bill in 1987, Bill C-22, Canadians have become clearly aware that the board's methodology in terms of looking at prices is flawed. The Patent Medicine Prices Review Board only monitors the price of old drugs already on the market. It does very little to address the issue of new products coming on the market.
I want to quote that the real increase in the cost of drugs on the market has risen well over the rate of
inflation. I want to point out as well that the following Canadian insurance plans have reported substantial increases in the prices of drugs since 1987: The Ontario government drug plan reports a 13.2 per cent increase; the Green Shield health insurance company reports an
11.4	per cent increase; the Manitoba health insurance plan has reported a 12.3 per cent increase. Now the government wants to offer less protection to consumers.
The fourth annual report of the PMPRB, which is a government board, ending December 31, 1991, admits that new drugs on the market have risen substantially since 1987. I want to quote from that report. "Even though price increases on existing drugs have been below inflation, the cost to consumers, third party insurers, and provincial drug plans have increased at a faster rate, chiefly because of the substitution of new drugs for those previously prescribed."
I could go on. I shall quote another study. It is a study prepared by the Department of Industry, Science and Technology entitled The Impact of Pharmaceutical Company-sponsored Basic Research at Canadian Universities. The report states: "In addressing the kinds of research and the amount that has taken place, Canadian medical schools have found that Bill C-22 has had a minimal impact on basic research and development in Canada".
This Bill C-22 that in essence destroyed compulsory licensing not only contributed to the increase in cost for medication, much of this medication going to seniors obviously and those people who are ill more than the average population, but contributed very little to research and development in this country.
This government board, the PMPRB, report said: "In relationship to the amount of activity in research and development, the location of significant research in the pharmaceutical industry is principally determined by the location of the parent firm's headquarters". There is proof that this bill is not going to do anything to generate significant additional research.
Further, in an OECD report entitled Multinational Enterprise: Governments and Technology the pharmaceutical industry states that whenever governments have tried to encourage pharmaceutical innovation in countries where it only exists at low levels-such as the case in Canada-the results have been disappointing.
November 17, 1992

What proof do we need that this is not the right type of legislation? A report from the department of the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs who introduced this bill shows that there has been limited job gain, little growth in basic research and almost no capacity to produce the active ingredients of drugs in Canada.
There had been a prediction in 1987 by the government that 3,000 jobs would be created by 1996. Another study concludes that only 1,386 jobs were created between 1987 and 1990, and nearly half of those were in marketing and sales. Only a third was in research and development, the area that the government had targeted for job creation.
You could look even further at those in research and development and realize that those that were taking place were not the kinds of jobs that we wanted primarily, although they were important jobs.
We opposed the last government intervention in this sector. We continue to oppose it because we believe that there is absolutely and totally inadequate proof that this is good for Canada, that this is good for Canadians and particularly for those Canadians who will need most assistance.

When I talk about Canadians who will need assistance with drugs and medicine, I am of course referring mainly to seniors. Except in rare cases, the need for medical attention tends to increase as we grow older. I suggest it is unfortunate that legislation such as this be allowed to cause hardship to the elderly.
There are those who are sick often, sometimes over the course of several years, and who will require medicine during most of their lives. Costs are already prohibitive. We suggest, and there is evidence to back this up, that they will only go higher with this legislation. I find it is absolutely irresponsible on the part of this government to go ahead with this.
I want to stress once more the fact that there is no adequate proof whatsoever to the effect that this bill will generate as many new jobs as government members claimed it will. Even if that many jobs were created, it would not be in the area they targeted, i.e. primarily research and development.
Government Orders
Why then has government decided to go ahead? [English]
I want to finish by stressing strongly that Bill C-91 will have very similar effects to the last bill, C-22. It will not, if it passes, create the number of jobs in the areas that it was indicated it would and it will not hold the cost down.
We have a number of really incredible studies which show that actually the contrary will occur. Therefore, with that kind of evidence and that kind of proof, I have no choice but to say no to Bill C-91 for those Canadians who will need medication and in particular the seniors and those who have need of medication because of their medical condition.

Mr. Speaker, I am privileged to say a few words on this bill.
Patent protection is something that is easy to attack but it is a very fundamental principle. In fact, when you read the history of the western world, it was only when we got into patent protection that gives to somebody who creates something new an exclusive period to use it and to profit from it that all sorts of people spent time and effort in writing books and developing products because of that patent protection. It led to an enormous creative energy that swept across the western world. We are benefiting from that today.
In the sixties the price of drugs started to go up. There is no doubt about that and governments around the world reacted in different ways. Virtually every other country in the world that acted at all acted in terms of a prices review board. But Canada did not act that way. The then government, which was a Liberal government, decided that it would abolish patent protection. In a way it seemed like a weird choice but that is in effect what it did. It immediately had an impact. It meant that there was less and less research being done in Canada, and why not?
If you were a scientist or were employing scientists and you wanted to develop a drug, would you put that money in Canada where you have a very limited protection? Or would you put it in Germany or Switzerland or Britain or France or the United States or any other number of countries in the world where you could get the patent protection for the period?

Government Orders
Of course you would put your money elsewhere and that is what started to happen. Just recently, we were faced with the loss of Connaught Laboratories Limited to a French company. That was an outflow of decisions that were taken years before because that is what we all learn as members. It takes many years for these things to come to fruition.
The company that developed insulin did so in this country. Had we kept the patent protection, we should have continued to be at the cutting edge. We lost out on Connaught Laboratories Limited and it is now owned by a French company.
In 1984 we proposed a remedy. It was Bill C-22. It was an enormous battle. The two opposition parties fought it tooth and nail. We stuck together as a caucus and got it through. As a result, even though it is just a short period of time, there are 2,400 people working that would not otherwise be working. One billion dollars has been spent on research and development since 1987. Once this bill goes through, we will have another $900 million of projects that are actually on the books and ready to move. We will have $84 million in research going to universities.
The point I want to make is that that bill was dramatically opposed by the opposition. We pushed it through and there are jobs. Those jobs would not have been created in the absence of it. Have any generic companies gone out of business? Not one. They are all here. Indeed, when you look at the generics, they have actually gone and made investments in the United States. If the generics are not being hurt and the prices of patented drugs have gone up by less than inflation then who is hurt? Nobody is hurt. We have 2,400 people working and we have over $1 billion in research.
A second bill that came along dealt with copyright. That too was opposed by both opposition parties but with less vigour. It went through. Again the principle is that if somebody writes something or creates something, they should be able to get some benefit from that for a period of exclusivity.
The third bill that came along was for microchip technology. We have 25 companies that build these microchips. They needed to have patent protection for the topography. This is how these microchips are designed. As you know, they are simply layers of silicone.
The people that design these are really like people that design apartments, figuring out how the water pipes go and the electrical pipes cords are put up and all that type of stuff.
By the time we got around to that bill, both opposition parties voted for it because they finally realized, I hope, that patent protection is good. On this bill they do not. I think it is really flowing out of their inability to stand up to Canadians and say the right thing. It is easy to oppose. It is an attractive thing to go out to seniors. There is no doubt that some of the stuff that has come from seniors shows that they have had the fear of God put in them because of some data that have come to them. Whether it is from the opposition parties or whether it is from the generic firms, it is out there and it is real.
The hard thing to do is to make a decision that is right for the country. Do we as a western country want to give up that historic patent protection that led to all sorts of creative ideas around the world? I do not think anyone would want to do that. It might appear attractive in the short term but it will sure hurt this country in the long term. Do we want our young kids in university to do the research to develop tire drugs? We are going to buy them. There is no doubt if a drug comes in and is designed in the United States, Germany or Switzerland and will help on cancer, our people will spend every cent they have. Do we do the research here and have our own people with all the multiplier effects or do we buy it from abroad?
I believe we should be doing it here. That is how this bill is designed. We have all the protections of the Patent Medicine Prices Review Board, the same as other countries. If the companies get too far out of line, the board has the power to act and it will act with the full support of this Parliament and the Canadian people.
In the meantime, why would we put one hand behind their back because other people will step in and do the research? As I said, has any generic company disappeared? The fact of the matter is that they have not. When we look into the drugs that the generics choose to get into, they choose a very narrow spectrum of drugs from which they make enormous profits without ever having put one cent into basic research and funding of that research to create that new drug. If anything is a parasitic relationship it is the generics.

Government Orders
I would rather have myself criticized for supporting companies that do that basic research to create the new one than to be acting on behalf of the few companies, the generics, that are taking the research of somebody else and creating it at a very low price without having paid for the research. That to me does not seem right.
I believe that the balance in this bill between the legitimate pharmaceutical companies and the generics and the population at large is a proper balance and I am proud to vote for this bill.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to take my place in the debate on this bill as well from the opposite point of view of the member who just spoke.

There have been a number of those kind of pay-offs to the American and multinational supporters of this government party. I am a bit concerned about one of the statements that was made by the House leader. Essentially what he said is that creators have the right to exploit their creations.
To some extent that should be true. There should be some protection for intellectual property and some protection for those scientists and researchers who do the fundamental research that ultimately results in good things being developed and in new developments being made in science and literature and other fields of human endeavour.
To suggest that patents and protection of intellectual property have been the great motivator for that kind of human endeavour misses the point of tens of thousands of years of human creativity. There were a lot of things invented before the inception of patent laws; things like the wheel, the steam engine and the automobile. There were a lot of things invented before we brought down patent legislation in order to protect this intellectual property.
I was interested in the House leader's statement because he said that creators have the right to exploit their creations. Essentially when we are looking at drug companies and companies that hold these patents we are not looking at the creators themselves, we are looking at people who have the power to deal with scientists and researchers and creators. They are able to buy up the results of those creations and exploit the results of those creations for their own profit. That is precisely what we are talking about here.
We are going beyond this because we are talking not about the right of a creator to exploit his creation, but about the right of manufacturers to exploit the people of Canada because they hold a government granted, time limited right to a patent that gives them the right, not to exploit their creation, but to exploit Canadian people in a monopolistic kind of situation.
That is what disturbs me because of the hypocrisy of this government. speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I yield the floor to the hon. member for Jonquiere, but first I would ask the co-operation of all members to hold private conversations outside the House.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak in this debate on the motion of the hon. member for Okanagan-Similkameen-Merritt. The motion reads as follows:
That, in the opinion of this House, the government should consider the advisability of developing a healthy small-business sector by targeting more federal contracts to the small-business sector and establishing a more aggressive Buy Canada program.
I read what certain members said in this House about this motion and I would like, first of all, to quote what the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood, a Liberal, a member of the opposition, said on this motion when he spoke of the Department of Supply and Services:
The department of which he is in charge is one of the most efficient and co-operative of all government services since it deals with small and medium-sized businesses.
He added:
It is fantastic.
In fact, nothing prevents a small or medium-sized business to deal with the federal government.
That goes to show you the difference in perception between members of this House. On the one hand, we have an NDP member who would like to see the system improved because he believes it is not efficient and, on the other hand, a Liberal member who thinks it is fantastic and it works pretty well. But how does it really work when it comes to awarding contracts to small businesses within Supply and Services Canada?
Eighty percent of all contracts-I repeat 80 per cent- which go to tender are awarded to small and mediumsized businesses. That leaves 10 per cent which are awarded to what we call big businesses, but also offered to small businesses. In a way, 90 per cent of Supply and Services contracts go to small and medium-sized businesses.
You will therefore understand that I am somewhat puzzled by the request put forth by the member from the
New Democratic Party who would like to improve the system. Could he tell us what exactly is the problem? Ninety per cent of contracts already go to small businesses. On top of that, for the last two years, the Minister of Supply and Services has created a system which is working or which at least allows our business people to use their computers to learn about the calls for tender put out by the government or by the Department of Supply and Services.
Under those circumstances, you will understand that what we hear from our small businesses, be it in the Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean area or in the riding of Jonquieres, or anywhere else in Quebec, is that people are pleased that the Department of Supply and Services has created this system to allow our small businesses to bid. They are ready to compete. All they ask is to have the opportunity to bid. It is what our government gave them two years ago.
That is why under the circumstances I really wonder if such a motion is not solely intended to allow the members to speak without achieving anything in terms of content since the system is working.
If the member is experiencing particular problems, there is an appeal mechanism for those businesses who feel that they were cheated. Judging by what we hear in the field from the business community and people, this mechanism is working just fine.
Ninety-seven per cent of businesses in Canada employ less than 50 people. Between 1981 and 1989, 81.5 per cent of jobs created in the country were in the small business sector.
For some contracts we have to take into account our GATT commitments; every contract over $204,000 must be open to foreign competitors. Do you know how many contracts that is, Mr. Speaker? Only 4.6 per cent of our contracts fall under this category according to the GATT agreement.
As far as the free trade agreement is concerned, there again certain provisions state that contracts for $25,000 and more must be open to foreign competition. However there are important exceptions which I will specify.
November 17, 1992

Areas like the police force, the Solicitor General, Justice, Fisheries and Oceans, Communications and National Defence are excluded; therefore, it represents 9 per cent or less of all contracts.
Let me go back to my opening remark. What we have put in place at Supply and Services is working out very well. Contractors say they are satisfied. They wanted to have the opportunity to bid and now they have it; not only that, they can even use their computers and know from day to day what goods and services our government needs. They are then in a better position to bid.
That is why I refuse to discuss this issue further because I feel that the motion proposed by the member is, to all intents and purposes, useless. People say they are happy with the present situation and if ever some improvements are in order, we will be very happy to see what can be done. Representing a riding where unemployment is high and where small businesses want work, you can rest assured that I would be the first one to do whatever is necessary to help them and make sure they have the opportunity to get contracts. As things stand right now, they say they have that opportunity.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to be able to participate in the debate this evening on this very important motion.
My colleague from Okanagan-Similkameen-Merritt has the vision to be able to see that the current system is not supporting small business and has put forward this motion as a means of asking the members of this House to demonstrate their support for small business and for the Buy Canadian program.
I have first-hand knowledge of many of the small businesses in my area and I can tell you, Mr. Speaker, that it confirms my colleague's concerns.
Last week I visited the Institute of Ocean Sciences, which is a federal facility in my riding, located on Pat Bay, for the commissioning of an oil spill recovery barge. One of the things the Institute of Ocean Sciences wanted to do when the facility was first commissioned was to attract those high-tech, high-paying small business firms to the area so that the spin-offs from the Institute of Ocean Sciences would create employment
Private Members' Business
and create all the spin-off benefits that small businesses generate in my area.
To a large degree that has happened. However, under this government there has been a rejection of that philosophy. It came first in 1989 with the dying of the unsolicited proposals program and those small businesses in the high-tech, high-paying field were strapped by the cancellation of that program.
They also were strapped because of the free trade agreement. The free trade agreement puts additional constraints and penalizes the small business sector in Canada.
Let me give a little background first. Of the number of businesses in Canada, 97 per cent are small businesses with less than 50 employees. That shows us all where the job creation potential is: 97 per cent of business in Canada is small business.
As I was saying, the free trade agreement has put further constraints on small business which has already been constrained by the high dollar, high interest rate policy of this government. Because of those three factors, over 13,000 businesses declared bankruptcy in
1991.	I think that demonstrates that we do need some sort of federal initiative to support the small business sector. They are the ones that create the jobs that create tax revenue for our government so that we can pay for our social programs and create a strong economy.
Under the General Agreement on Thriffs and Trade, the federal government does not have to put out to tender those bids that are under $204,000. So the federal government can buy Canadian under GATT if it does not exceed $204,000. This is a fairly reasonable bidding process. Until the free trade agreement that was the relationship between Canada and the U.S. Under that agreement the bidding was dropped down to $29,000, which does not buy a whole lot, particularly in the high-tech, high-paying jobs that we want to create in our country, with the kind of benefits we would have in technology and education.
This would be annoying enough, even as it stands, if it were not for the kind of difference that the United States enjoys. It enjoys an advantage over us because it does not suffer from the same sort of provisions. They have a Buy America Act which protects, to a much greater degree, their small business sector.

November 17, 1992
Private Members' Business
In my riding of Saanich-Gulf Island those high-tech environmental technology firms are creating high-tech, high paying jobs, not the Mac jobs that this government is so proud of having created, not the $5 an hour jobs, but real jobs that can support real families, that can support real communities, that add to our tax base, that add to the wealth in our society, that are able to pay for higher education so we can actually have a future for our children and for our country.
What we also have incorporated in my colleague's motion is that there has to be more support for Buy Canada programs, and there has to be.
At the meeting of the Institute of Ocean Sciences last Thursday I was shown a particular computer modelling system and this modelling system was beautiful to behold. It had the map of Vancouver Island on the computer screen and the capability of that facility, as the promotional material showed, is not a computer mapping tool or geographic information system but it is the kind of management tool for making decisions.
It takes the map of Vancouver Island and if I were to ask what if an oil spill happened on Galiano Island, or in the Gulf of Georgia, that computer is able to look at the tides, the wind conditions, all of the situations which would determine where the oil is going to end up. Then our federal resources, the Canadian Coast Guard, the province of British Columbia, would know where to put their resources to clean it up.
This is the kind of technology that is available in Canada that we should be buying, that we should be protecting, creating jobs in our own community. Right now that is not happening and it is because of the sort of wrong-headed approach that the market is the salvation for all things. This government has forsaken those people who have created, who have had the initiative to go out and risk a lot of capital in developing these high tech tools for decision making.
In conclusion, I strongly urge the members of this House to support my colleague's motion, to show some vision for the 1990s and into the next century. We have the capability in Canada to provide the environmental technologies that will benefit not only our own communities, not only our own country, but the world.
I think we have a responsibility to be able to share that with the world.
Please vote yes on this initiative.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to contribute in this debate on a very important issue raised by the hon. member for Okanagan-Similka-meen-Merritt.
I easily understand why my colleague would move this motion, which I agree is in itself quite good, but I have serious questions on its relevance.
Let me read the motion, Mr. Speaker, and then I will comment.
That. . . the government should consider the advisability of
developing a healthy small business sector-
I will read the remainder later on.
If my colleague wants to develop a healthy small business sector, it seems to me that this is not a good time to present such a motion because, as far as I know, economic, fiscal and tax policies announced in different budgets, including the last one, did foster through special initiatives the development of businesses so that they may become a healthy sector. We should not forget that small businesses represent two thirds of our economy.
The first part of the motion leaves me unsatisfied, because the development of a healthy small business sector is already well under way.
I go back to the motion:
-developing a healthy small-business sector in Canada by
targeting more federal contracts to the small-business sector-
I will get back to the rest.
A moment ago, my colleague for Jonquiere reminded us of some very interesting statistics. If we want to grant federal government contracts in larger numbers, we have to know what the situation is. Let me repeat the statistics recalled by my colleague for Jonquiere. Already 90 per cent of the federal contracts are awarded, allocated to the small and medium-sized business sector in Canada. I might also add that through subcontracting from this sector, another 10 per cent of contracts are going to other small businesses. Nearly 90 per cent of those contracts go straight to the small business sector. I realize that we may not have achieved 100 percent, Mr. Speaker, but you have to admit that as currently worded this motion seems to be off the point. For my part I
November 17, 1992

favour the new program, the new contract allocation policy has found in my own area, in my own riding of Richmond-Wolfe.
Many Chambers of Commerce are intensely involved in favouring the granting of such contracts in their area. I think particularly of the Eastern Townships, and I could also mention Richmond-Wolfe. If already 90 per cent of contracts are awarded to the small business sector, I fail to see how this motion should get our approval. While being virtuous per se, 100 per cent is nothing but wishful thinking.
I now come to the last feature, and I will quote if I may the rest of the hon. member's motion:
- targeting more federal contracts to the small-business sector and
establishing a more aggressive "Buy Canada" program.
Here perhaps could we take most exception to this motion, beyond the virtue it commends. There are obstacles to boosting a Buy Canada program. For instance, we live in an international market framework: there is the free trade with the United States and soon with Mexico, and it is ages since we are exporting and importing outside of those two markets. Canada is already known as an exporting country and its whole economy is largely reliant on export.
What happens? If we introduce what I would call a restrictive policy based directly on the Buy Canada principle, you can easily imagine how our international partners would react to such a policy, as commendable as it may be. The Buy Canada principle obviously has its merits. It is a goal that can be achieved through awareness programs and publicity. It is not hard to figure out that a strict governmental policy to that effect would soon be under attack.
In that regard, the last element may be the most difficult to achieve, whereas the other two that I mentioned earlier are already under way.
Of course, we can use the Canadian content to encourage people to buy Canadian. That is precisely where the policy of this government has played a role. Instead of imposing a restrictive, disciplinary not to say dictatorial policy, we chose other ways to encourage our people to buy Canadian, mainly by insisting more and more on a Canadian content for all our products. It can
Private Members' Business
be done. There were up to nine policies before whereas we have only one today. We have managed to simplify the whole system relating to federal contracts.
That brings me, Mr. Speaker, to tell you this. I understand very well the good faith of my colleague from Okanagan and the validity of this motion. But I am not sure that it has a place here in the circumstances that we know, especially with its wording that causes some problems.
To sum up, as far as I am concerned, we have followed much tighter policies in order to establish and develop a healthier small business sector, and we have made good progress so far. You only have to think about the last tax decreases, incentives to businesses and loans in some cases, all aimed at making credit more easily available. So, I think we have made progress on the first element.
About the second one, as I mentioned earlier, more contracts is exactly what we have achieved with the new policy put forward by the minister these last three years. All businesses have access to government contracts and all managers, presidents or purchasing officers can bid through their own computer. What more can you ask for when you can practically access this information from your own home?
I do not think this second element can be discarded, quite the opposite. It is under way and things are going very well indeed. It is the last element I worry about, and that is why I am dead against this motion, because this third objective seems unrealistic and unachievable.
Therefore, Mr. Speaker, I invite my colleague to reword his motion. Of course, the motion is now before us, before the House, but you will understand why I, among others, will have to stand against the motion on behalf of small businesses, given the achievements of our government.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to stand in this House today to speak to the motion which simply calls upon the government to consider the advisability of developing a healthy small business sector in Canada by targeting more federal contracts to the small business sector and establishing a more aggressive Buy Canada program.

November 17, 1992
Private Members' Business
I listened quite carefully to the previous speaker and I have read and reread this motion. For the life of me, I cannot imagine why anybody would want to vote against it. It is something that is straightforward and it is nothing more than developing a healthy, small business sector in Canada. I do not think that the mover of the motion could want any more than that and certainly I could not either.
I fully support this motion as I recognize the vital role that small business plays in Canada. Indeed, 40 per cent of Canadians work for small business and between 1978 and 1987-1 notice that we all have different figures here-93 per cent of all new jobs were created by small business. These facts clearly show that small business is the engine of growth and new job opportunity in this country.
In October 1990 I wrote in a little local newspaper in my riding of Nepean, The Clarion, that these days entrepreneurs are confronted by market globalization, world-wide competition and increasingly demanding consumers. At the same time, the speed of change in world markets is in product development. Even global political systems are accelerating at a rate few would have imagined.
For Canadian small business, each of these changes has brought the issues of quality and productivity to the forefront and many people in the city of Nepean work in small business, as I said previously. Most talk of the need to compete head on with the best companies in the world.
They point out that to do so, our companies must do more than simply match the price, services and design of competitors on a local and regional scale. They must compete on the larger global scale. They must make their wares and services attractive and accessible to an expanding marketplace.
In an era of fewer and fewer trade barriers, consumers all over the world have free access to the highest quality products at the lowest possible prices. The result is simple. We have to become ever more competitive, we have to explore every avenue and take advantage of every opportunity to exploit the marketplace.
What has this government done to help small business in Canada?
As I review the past eight years I do not see much. I look at the GST. I would like to say that I consistently
receive letters from constituents who own and work in small businesses. The overwhelming majority of them complain about the burden that has been placed on their businesses as a result of this unfair tax grab.
They write about the cost of and the difficulty in getting access to capital to expand their businesses. They write that the Small Businesses Loans Act and the Federal Business Development Bank do not seem to be in tune with the needs of small business.
At a time when many businesses have gone bankrupt in the last couple of years, I am hearing over and over again that banks are calling loans on small businesses. They are shutting down small business. What are we doing about it? What is this government doing about it? Not very much.
The government failed to reform the bankruptcy legislation until thousands of small firms went out of business. High interest rates combined with a high dollar gave us a made-in-Canada recession from which we are still trying to recover. All this government has given us is a hollow prosperity initiative. It offers no meaningful solutions.
As this motion says, the federal government should endeavour to target more federal contracts to the small business sector and to establish a more aggressive Buy Canada program. This is but one step toward encouraging this vitally important Canadian sector.
But more needs to be done. We have to address the issue of access to capital. We need to have export programs which will encourage small and medium sized firms to look outward. Currently less than 10 per cent of Canadian firms export. This has to be changed. We need to look at countries like Germany which have aggressive export programs.
There is much the Government of Canada could be doing to help small businesses prosper and grow in this country. I believe it is high time something be done. I certainly can support this motion.

Mr. Speaker, I congratulate my colleague from Okanagan-Similka-meen-Merritt for putting forward this motion. I very much appreciate the words of the hon. member for Nepean. It is worth while to draw the attention of members to the wording of this motion because it is wording that members all sides of the House should be supporting. Essentially it says:


November 17, 1992

That, in the opinion of this House, the government should consider
the advisability of developing a healthy small business sector.
I wonder who could possibly be against that. The hon. member for Okanagan-Similkameen-Merritt proposes that we target federal contracts to the small business sector and establish a more aggressive Buy Canada program.
I cannot understand how a government that is thinking properly would reject this motion or reject the ideas contained in this motion, or a government that pretends to be a government for Canadians by Canadians in Canada. It simply does not make sense that government speakers would stand in this House and say, first, that they are against enhancing small business and, second, that they are against expanding the Buy Canada program and providing contracts to small businesses in order to encourage those businesses to grow and strive.
As my colleague pointed out these are businesses, depending on what figures we use, that create somewhere between 80 and 90 per cent of all new jobs in this country.
I heard the Minister of Finance, the Minister for International Trade and the Prime Minister talk this morning about the G-7, the World Bank and international agencies like the OECD, congratulating Canada for having all its fundamentals in the right place.
One fundamental that is not in the right place is jobs. This government should be about creating jobs. Well over one million Canadians are collecting welfare and unemployment insurance; 11.4 per cent of Canadian workers have no jobs to go to.
If the small business sector is responsible for creating somewhere between 80 per cent and 90 per cent of all employment in Canada then, by gosh, rather than having Conservative members standing in this House and rejecting a motion calling for the enhancement of small business by encouraging a Buy Canada program or providing more contracts to small business, they should have been on their hind feet demanding that the opposition present a motion like this one and indicating that they were going to be voting for it.
Private Members' Business
This is one of the problems with this government. When a motion comes from the opposition it refuses to listen to it. It refuses to accept good advice.
Unfortunately I heard the Prime Minister speaking at a meeting last night, I think it was in Montreal, in which he admitted that he was one of the most unpopular prime ministers in the history of this country because he thinks he was doing the right thing rather than the popular thing.
He is unpopular because he has been doing the wrong thing. He has not listened to Canadians. He has not listened to advice outside his own caucus and outside his own political advisers. That is why he is the most unpopular prime minister this country has ever had.
My colleague presents a very reasonable, reasoned motion. It came from the small business people in his riding and across the country he is in contact with. Yet the government rejects it out of hand. Why? It is because it came from the opposition. There can be no other logical reason for rejecting it.
In a speech a few months ago supporting this motion my colleague pointed out that even our major neighbour to the south, our major trading partner, has a similar program that has been very beneficial to small business in the United States. He pointed out that in 1989, under the U.S. Small Businesses Act, 18 per cent of prime contracts and 39 per cent of subcontracts representing a total value of $59 billion were awarded to small business. Of these, $13 billion in contracts were specifically designated by contractor officers as being set aside exclusively to the U.S. small business concerns.
Our major trading partner, the one we have joined in a free trade agreement, has a policy like this to encourage indigenous small business in the United States, and speakers on the Conservative side express some concern that our trading partners might get a little worried if we have a buy Canadian program for small business.
Everybody is going to be worried if a government that represents itself as a Government of Canada and for Canadians does not support a program like this one. It would be very surprising for me if the Conservative government and Conservative members stood in the House and voted against this motion because they felt it did not make sense. It would indicate they are against small business in Canada if they are against this kind of a

Private Members' Business
Buy Canada program and support in the form of contracts to small businesses.
There are other areas of small business I would like to talk about for a few seconds before closing wherein this government has taken actions which have had the result of creating problems for small businesses that want to get into exports. A few minutes ago the Minister of Forestry was in the House. He has indicated in past months that he was supportive of secondary manufacturing of forest products in British Columbia.
However, a manufacturer in my riding manufactures furniture and framing component blanks for export to the northeast United States market. He exports them all across the United States to the northeast United States from the east coast of Vancouver Island. He had a problem with one of his receivables. He had a fraudulent purchase of his products. As a result the Export Development Corporation jacked up his premiums on his receivables insurance which just about drove him out of business.
What kind of way is that to support and encourage the development of secondary forest products manufacturing in British Columbia and the development of new export markets by small businesses into the United States and elsewhere in the world?
This government has taken action which has been deleterious to small business in Canada. I really cannot understand it and I cannot understand the attitude on the part of those members who say: "Since we did not think of this motion we are not going to support it". That is basically their attitude. The problem is that they have been taking their own advice for too long. That is why they are unpopular. That is why we have the most unpopular Prime Minister of Canada. That is why at the next election small business people along with other workers and other people in this country are go to rise up and throw the Conservatives out. Why do they not listen to good advice for a change?
This is a motion that is worth supporting. My colleague got the idea for this motion from the small business people this motion intends to support.
I would urge my Conservative colleagues to reconsider the hard line position they have taken against support of this motion. Small business people are watching then-attitude about this motion and about small business in general.
I want to wind up by repeating this motion and questioning why Conservative members cannot vote for it. It states:
That, in the opinion of this House, the government should
consider the advisability of developing a healthy small business
sector in Canada-
How can they be against that? It continues:
-by targeting more federal contracts to the small business sector-
Are they against that? It continues:
-and establishing a more aggressive Buy Canada program.
How could the Conservatives be against that? They should stand up and support this country for a change and vote for this motion.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to speak on this motion. Since he seems to have a very short memory, I would like to remind him of a few things. When we introduced the last federal budget, which raised the small business loans to $200,000 from $100,000, his party voted against it. They voted against the interests of small businesses of this country, responsible for creating jobs; they voted against helping small businesses get operating capital
November 17, 1992

and better businesses opportunities. He motions that it is no so, but I remind him that his party voted against the last federal budget.
We have signed regional development agreements with each of the provinces; in the west we have set up a structure to help business, as in the maritimes and in Quebec. We created specific programs in specific business areas.
I would like to underscore another important point. When we were debating Bill C-22, which was to generate major investments in Quebec as well as other Canadians provinces like Manitoba, they voted against it. Today, these same people rise in the House of Commons to tell Canadians that the government is not sensitive to the needs of the small business sector. These same people, New Democrats in particular, were against tax credits to businesses because they allegedly do not pay they fair share. These same individuals said no. But they are proud, for example, of the dispute settlement tribunal that was put in place with the Americans so that we could solve important issues like pork and other issues like lumber, that will come later. It is also important that other international communities know that Canada does things perfectly and properly. But where were the members of the Opposition? They were hiding behind their desks, because they were scared to defend effectively the interests of their constituents, their communities and their businesses, as our government and the Minister of Forestry do, as did the Minister of Finance during the last budgets, and as the Minister of Regional Development does, in order that-

Mr. Speaker, on April 28 I asked the Minister of Employment and Immigration why the day before he had implemented changes to the domestic workers program while the standing committee was still studying his proposals of January 30 and the committee had not yet reported. The minister had asked a committee to study certain proposals and before we finished studying the proposals, he implemented the changes he had proposed.
At the time I said this was an insult to the parliamentary committee and made a farce out of so-called parliamentary reform. It is interesting to note that the majority of members on that committee were Conservative Party members and the chairman was a member of the Conservative Party, but despite that the minister ignored the committee and went ahead.
I also pointed out to the minister that not one witness appearing before the committee up until that time had supported the proposals the minister had suggested. As a matter of fact he had not even consulted with any of those witnesses.
Since that time, the committee has tabled its unanimous report. It was tabled on July 28 and it disagrees with the new measures introduced by the minister on April 27. Under the minister's new program, domestic workers must have the equivalent of grade 12 in Canada and six months' full-time training.

Adjournment Debate
It is very rare for domestics to go through to grade 12 in the countries they come from and there is no course for domestic workers in any countries except England and the United States. Where are the people from the Caribbean and the Philippines to get these courses? They may have grade 12 but that is a high level of education in those countries.
Since 1981, when the Liberal Party introduced this program, 60,000 women have come to Canada to serve as domestics. Many stayed and went on to better things. Prior to the minister's changes, a woman only needed one year of experience as a domestic. She did not need a grade 12 education or a formal course. If she had experience of one year working in a home with children, that was good enough to get her into the country as a domestic, if she showed the right sort of compassion and care for children. After two years of good work as a domestic, she was given the privilege of applying as a permanent resident, as a landed immigrant.
The committee unanimously said that it did not want grade 12 or the six months' training to be the sole criteria but that there should be a wide range of flexible criteria, including the experience of the woman as a domestic.
The minister said on April 28 when I raised this question: "If hon. members on the committee come up with recommendations to improve this program I will look at them seriously. I do not think this takes away from the efforts of the committee or the subcommittee".
The report has been out since July 28. We have not had any response from the minister yet. It is true he has until December 24 to respond. However, I am hopeful the government will listen to a unanimous committee report of this Parliament, have respect for that committee and in this case make changes to this program which are reasonable changes and not blindly follow the proposals of the minister.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in response to the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, I would like to bring to his attention some of the details, some of the background and some of the reasoning for the changes.
As he knows, after several years of consultation the new live-in caregiver program was introduced on April 27,1992 to replace what was the former Foreign Domestic Movement Program. This program continues to be the government's policy of meeting a labour market demand for live-in caregivers by facilitating the entry into Canada of trained and qualified workers. Several elements of the live-in caregiver program are specifically targeted to reduce the exploitation of domestic workers-which I know he would be concerned about-such as a model contract of employment and more information on the respective rights and responsibilities that they have.
The live-in caregiver program requires a grade 12 education and six months of training in the caregiving field. This reflects the level of responsibility given to live-in caregivers and recognizes the skills required to work independently in a caregiving role.
The education level required under the new program also reflects the realities of the Canadian labour market. Tvo-thirds of the new jobs in Canada by the year 2000 will require a minimum of 12 years of education.
Last year close to 60 per cent of all persons who landed under the foreign domestic program had over 12 years of education. These education requirements will lessen the chance of abuse as the worker will be better able to understand his or her rights and how to seek redress should these rights be infringed upon.
In answer to the concerns of the hon. member, the government appreciates the sound research of the Standing Committee on Labour, Employment and Immigration on this issue. I want to assure him that the minister and the department are reviewing the recommendations made by his committee.

Mr. Speaker, on May 7, 1992, I raised a question with the Minister of Employment and Immigration in which I tried to show the minister that there was an important link between work and education, particularly with respect to young people. I pointed out to the minister that tuition fees had gone up and were continuing to increase substantially,

making it more difficult for these young men and women to stay in school, college and university.
I pointed out that the student debt was going totally out of sight. We now have a debt load that people may never be able to repay. I stressed that there were waiting lists of up to two years for people waiting get into a program, that there were thousands of students as of that date without meaningful jobs. Of the very few jobs that were available, they were short-term, poorly remunerated, they would not last, they were dead end. They did very little to contribute to the education, the training or retraining of that particular person. I found that was really very deplorable.
On that particular date I recall we were not only talking about line-ups of over two years of applications but in one university in the city of Winnipeg, it was estimated that 300 people would lose their jobs. I wanted the minister to understand that these kinds of conditions are really demoralizing. They destroy our cities, our provinces, our country. My question was: Why had the government permitted this to happen?
In response the minister said that they were relying on the prosperity initiative to set things straight. What the minister did not understand is that there are problems that have to be dealt with immediately, today. If there is a fire you do not plan how you are going to get out and when you are going to get out. That should have been done before. You get out. After that you try to make sure that it does not happen again.
There are real needs out there. People are without jobs, tuition fees are increasing, the debt load is skyrocketing. What was the minister doing? Relying upon the prosperity initiative. Then he said: "Let us co-operate".

I am quite willing to co-operate. I gave him so may ideas, I do not understand why he did not do anything, nothing at all, six months after having said that.

Here are some of the things I suggested. The 3 per cent tax on student loans for those students who need to borrow so they are among the poorest of the poor students, eliminate it. Do not increase by six months the
Adjournment Debate
interest that has to be paid on student loans. Eliminate the GST on books and reading materials. This government had a wonderful opportunity and it denied it, it stopped it.
I said we should make sure we have appropriate summer jobs for these young men and women so they can help pay for the education they want so they can become contributing members of society. I did say stop slashing education, training, retraining, research and development. Come to grips with reality today. Six months later nothing has been done. We are still relying on the prosperity initiative and I fear for the future.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on May 191 asked a question in the House of the Minister of Forestry on a very important trade matter that is still before us. It is the whole question of the softwood lumber tariff dispute Canada is having with the United States.
I raised two important questions in that question to the minister that I would like to touch on briefly tonight and hopefully get a response from the government.
The first was the point following the delegation of New Democrat MPs to Washington, D.C. on this issue that clearly the whole basis behind the tariff dispute with the United States is the American attempt to grab our raw resources, in particular our raw logs, and ship them to the United States. They said that to us in very clear terms in Washington and it is clearly an issue that this Parliament and this government are going to have to deal with.
They also raised, as did we, the important issue of how to resolve this particular dispute. At that time the government was saying not to worry, the free trade agreement would save us, the dispute panels that would be set up under the free trade agreement would deal with the softwood lumber issue.
In Washington we were told by the commerce department that it had no opinion on this particular issue and that we would have to wait and see whether, even as weak as they are, the dispute panels can be used to try and resolve this issue. It is ironic that this question is
being raised today because today in Washington there was to have been a panel hearing in which the U.S. lumber lobby, using every opportunity it has to try to thwart Canada's exports of softwood to the United States, was to have presented a motion basically suggesting that these dispute panels do not even have jurisdiction on the whole softwood question.
We understand that one of the American panel members, for whatever reason, was not able to attend today so the hearing was put off. It is very clear to all of us who are concerned about this issue from lumber exporting communities that the American political process, from the President on down to the U.S. lumber lobby, will use every effort, legitimate or not, to try and thwart our exports. That is clear from the attempted motion today which will obviously be brought forward at a later date. It is also clear from the recent petitioning of President-elect Clinton, who comes from Arkansas, one of the lumber producing states in the United States. The interest is to triple the current 6.5 per cent tariff on Canadian lumber exports.
It is a very clear and important issue for all of Canada, in particular my home province of British Columbia as a lumber exporter. In this ongoing trade dispute we have seen the failure of the free trade agreement to address this issue. It is a specific example of that. We may have to wait until April of next year before this issue might even possibly be dealt with, and even then we do not know if it is going to be dealt with in Canada's favour.
It is a critical issue, it is one that was raised in May. It is still relevant today, perhaps even more relevant given the whole question of the failure of the free trade agreement to tiy and resolve this issue.
I would ask the government to seriously review its position on this question. What is the state of this dispute panel mechanism? Can we rely on the government's assurances any more? I ask for some action from the government on this issue.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to respond to the hon. member for Prince George-Bulkley Valley regarding his question and raise whether article 2009 of the free trade agreement concerning the softwood lumber MOU precludes the appeal of the results of the countervailing duty investigation.

Article 1904 of the free trade agreement provides that either party may request a binding binational panel review following a final subsidy dumping or injury determination in the countervailing duty.
We have exercised our rights under the FTA and we have established chapter 19 panels to rule on the U.S. subsidy and the injury findings. On September 29, 1992 the U.S. Lumber Industry Coalition, as the member may know, filed a motion to dismiss the FTA chapter 19 panel examining the commerce department's final subsidy determination for lack of jurisdiction.
There is no question that the panel has jurisdiction to hear Canada's appeal. FTA article 2009 does not exempt the case from panel review. Canada and the United States have both filed briefs with the panel stating categorically that the panel has the exclusive jurisdiction to hear this appeal. We have confidence in the FTA dispute settlement process which has served us so well in the pork case and as well in the recent case involving live swine exports.
The resolution of this case is a priority of the government and we are resolved to exercise all our rights under the free trade agreement and the GATT in defence of our trade interests.
The federal government, the provinces and, I would like to remind the hon. member, the industry remain united in their determination to fight this case to the very bitter end and I thank him for his concern.

Mr. Speaker, I raised the matter of the Westray mine disaster on May 21 and again the following day because there were so many unanswered questions. Six months later those questions still remain unanswered.
I was one of several of my colleagues, including in particular my friend and colleague from Cape Breton-East Richmond, understandably determined to get to the bottom of this tragic affair, as are the families of the 26 men who lost their lives in that tragedy.
Last week's decision by Madam Justice Glube of the Nova Scotia Supreme Court, a decision which is certainly a fair ruling based on the law, leaves the Nova Scotia government with veiy few options. There is a government which does have some options, the same options it
Adjournment Debate
has had for six months and has refused to exercise, the government that sits opposite.
The time has come for this government to relent and to establish a federal inquiry. Nothing in Madam Justice Glube's decision would rule out or prevent this government from taking that initiative and holding its own inquiry.
We on this side and in particular my colleague from Cape Breton-East Richmond are calling today on the government to establish either a public inquiry into this or a standing committee assigned, similar to the one we held into the Al-Mashat affair last year.
That inquiry ought to be held without delay for several good reasons. One is that a dangerous precedent was established in this affair when the interests of political parties clearly overruled advice given by federal civil servants concerned with safety and the economic feasibility of that project. These officials ought to be given an opportunity to testify to that effect without any fear of reprisal.
Second, the Prime Minister must be called to testify as to his involvement in this affair. A senior official of Curragh Resources, Marvin Pelley, said that the Prime Minister was the facilitator in this. The member for Central Nova, the Minister of Public Works, and the premier, Mr. Cameron, stated in interviews with the Halifax paper The Chronicle Herald that without the help of the Prime Minister the project would have been killed. That is a direct quote from these men.
Third, the member himself, the Minister of Public Works, has had an involvement in this. He was involved in silencing the opposition of federal bureaucrats on this issue. That is well documented, and that needs to be scrutinized by a public inquiry or a standing committee.
Fourth, a committee of cabinet looked at this matter in
1988.	What was it told by federal bureaucrats? Was the advice to proceed? What was the advice? Let us call these people and let us table the documents before a proper inquiry and have this issue out in the open once and for all.
Finally, Clifford Frame has been curiously successful in getting his way with this government in terms of financial assistance for his mining projects, although mining is hardly within his bailiwick.

Adjournment Debate
We need to get to the bottom of this one. We owe it to those people. We owe it to the country as a whole. We owe it to the taxpayers. We owe it to people who believe in safety, who believe that safety ought to be a consideration when we are giving public assistance.
Why was a well ordered and defined decision-making process influenced by questionable political interests? That is just one of the many questions we need to get an answer to. Mr. Speaker, I think you agree we need to get to the bottom of this one.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member should know that the federal government does not have the jurisdiction in the area of occupational health and safety.
This is the responsibility of the provincial government. Notwithstanding this fact though, the Government of Canada took a variety of measures consistent with our role as a financial guarantor to ensure that the project he speaks of was technically safe and viable.
The initial environmental assessment, the Acres report, pointed out the key health and safety concerns associated with coal mines and the methods that the company was putting in place to overcome these concerns. All concerns including those pointed out by the Devco report were deemed to be correctable with known technology.
The CANMET review spoke briefly of mine ventilation and spontaneous combustion risk. It concluded that in spite of these technical uncertainties the proposal had no major technical failings. Westray was required to comply with all the appropriate coal mining regulations in Nova Scotia including those dealing with mine ventilation and spontaneous combustion matters and regular provincial mine inspections were carried out.
According to the mining industry, the causes and mechanisms of coal dust explosions are well understood through past research. It is the responsibility of the operators and the regulators to apply that knowledge base in developing control strategies.
We put in place steps to ensure that the company was in full compliance with the provincial regulatory standards and in health and safety. This was monitored on a monthly basis by independent mining consultants. All of these facts were taken into consideration before making the decision to fund this project by the federal government.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have this occasion to review a question that I posed to the Solicitor General last May 5,1992. It had to do with the serious problem of drug trafficking and drug abuse that unfortunately has afflicted all too many Canadians and certainly afflicted all too many neighbourhoods across our country, particularly in a large urban centre like metropolitan Toronto.
I do not want to suggest that we ought to be negative or have a doom and gloom approach to the situation. I believe that we have to lay the cards on the table and begin to realize that some of those neighbourhoods which are under siege by these drug traffickers are in fact losing the battle. Governments are perhaps losing the battle. For average Canadians and their neighbours living in those neighbourhoods and communities, the feelings by long measure are feelings of wanting to triumph over this serious cancer that is spreading and touching the lives of too many Canadians and particularly our young.
Therefore, I have had thousands of names put to petitions deposited on the floor of this House of Commons. I had the opportunity on several occasions of asking the Solicitor General and the Minister of Justice as to what their answer would be on one particular aspect of fighting drugs on the streets. That one aspect happened to be the amendment to the Narcotics Control Act so as to share the assets that flow from any drug seizure. Rather than having all those assets flow back exclusively to the federal treasury, there could be a shared arrangement by which some of those assets would flow back to the local authorities, whether they be the municipal government or the police affiliates or in fact local organizations so that those entities which are on the leading edge of that battle, not those in the background, for instance, as the federal government in Ottawa, would have at their disposal some assets that would further the cause of putting back and stemming what seems to be a growing tide.
Ib his credit, the Solicitor General has said on a number of occasions, and in fact responded to my question, that he is in agreement with the general principle. He has been saying that for a veiy long time. He has also been saying for a very long time that legislation to amend the Narcotics Control Act is just around the comer.


It has been a very, very long comer indeed because we have not seen the legislation. We have the good intentions of the minister in his responses to this Chamber, but thus far we have not seen the realization or the fruition of bringing those amendments before the House of Commons at which point I believe there would be relatively speedy passage from all sides of the House because of the urgent need to do so.
Therefore, this evening I am looking forward to perhaps the parliamentary secretary giving us specifics and indicating that in fact we are not only paying lip service to this very urgent need but that the government is prepared to specifically with time constraints and agendas say yes, we are prepared to move and this is when and this is how.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the whole subject is a little more complicated than the impression you might have gathered from the comments of the hon. member.
First of all, I think it should be pointed out that Canada's Criminal Code and its drag legislation does have provisions designed to attack the profit motive in a wide variety of crimes, not just narcotics crimes.
The ability of the Crown to apply for forfeiture of the proceeds of specified offences severely undermines the obvious profit motive for committing those offences.
This is a particularly effective tool in Canada's drug enforcement initiative. Sharing those forfeited assets with other jurisdictions should not be equated with giving the police another tool for the battle against drugs.
The hon. member's questions assumed that the forfeited assets are necessary in order to finance local law

enforcement efforts. This seems dangerously close to making forfeitures the driving force for undertaking drug investigations.
The carnage, as he pointed out, caused by the drug trade is the reason behind these investigations. The ability to seize proceeds is an ancillary benefit. Any sharing of that benefit would be undertaken as a matter of fairness and not as the rationale for undertaking investigations. The simple fact is that many other enterprise crime investigations lead to forfeiture of assets, but this has not led to a demand for sharing in order to win the battle against those crimes.
It may in fact be the best indicator that the issue of sharing deserves careful examination, which the Solicitor General has indicated to the House he would do. Perhaps reimbursement of expenses may be appropriate, but viewing law enforcement as a business is not appropriate.
There is a popular myth that suggests that drug traffickers have rooms full of cash available for seizure and forfeiture. This view of assets available from drug seizures may drive the claim for sharing since this is an obvious source for enforcement revenues. I support the active use of our proceeds of crime scheme.
